section.title: The setup element
section.para: The setup element defines the data-copying operations to be performed.

attribute.name: usecase
attribute.para: Name of the usecase this setup is for. This becomes the name of the subdirectory where the usecase results are stored.

attribute.name: directory-id
attribute.para: Defines the identifier for the base usecase directory. See common attributes for a usage example.

attribute.name: source-project-name
attribute.para: The name of the project (directory) to be used. Overrides a value for this defined on a parent element.

element.name: macros
element.para: Define simple macros for use in attributes and text. See simple macro expansion.

element.name: copy-data
element.para: Copies retrieved ADA documents to application/version specific sub-directories.

element.name: copy-project-schemas
element.para: Copies project schemas to application/version specific sub-directories.

element.name: empty-directory
element.para: Creates an empty directory (or empties an existing one).

element.name: copy-directory
element.para: Copies a directory, optionally with subdirectories, to an application/version specific sub-directory.

element.name: retrieve
element.para: Retrieves a single XML document from a REST URL and stores this in an application/version specific sub-directory.

entry.para: Although not strictly necessary (non-existent directories are created by the build steps as well), it is advised that the setup creates all directories, empty or not. This ensures that, during the setup process, these directories are emptied. It also allows referring to these directories using the directory identifier mechanism.

Some components have commands that allow developers to compare the XML results created here against the XML results of the original (Ant based) system. By default, all directories that are created are compared. You can stop this comparison by adding a compare="false" attribute. This allows you to add (usually empty) directories for documents that are not created in the original code, like reports. Directories created with copy-directory are never compared (because this was meant for copying fixed resources).

section.title: The copy-data element
section.para: The copy-data element defines which files must be copied, and to where.

attribute.name: target-subdir
attribute.para: The name of the sub-directory to copy the data to.

attribute.name: source-subdir
attribute.para: The name of the source sub-directory. Base directory and default depends on the component it is used in.

attribute.name: directory-id
attribute.para: Defines the identifier for the target sub-directory. See common attributes for a usage example.

attribute.name: compare
attribute.para: Whether this directory should be included in a comparison with results of the original code.

attribute.name: compare-flags
attribute.para: Specific settings for comparing this directory with the results of the original code. See below for details.

attribute.name: clear-target
attribute.para: Whether to clear the target directory before copying.

element.name: include
element.para: Definition of any files to include. See include/exclude elements

element.name: exclude
element.para: Definition of any files to exclude. See include/exclude elements

section.title: The copy-project-schemas element
section.para: The copy-project-schemas element defines which schemas (from a project definition) must be copied, and to where. The location for source project files is defined using parameter projectsBaseStorageDirectory.

attribute.name: target-subdir
attribute.para: The name of the sub-directory to copy the data to.

attribute.name: copy-ada-meta
attribute.para: Whether to copy the default ada_meta.xsd schema also.

attribute.name: source-project-name
attribute.para: The name of the project (directory) to be used. Overrides a value for this defined on a parent element.

attribute.name: directory-id
attribute.para: Defines the identifier for the target sub-directory. See common attributes for a usage example.

attribute.name: compare
attribute.para: Whether this directory should be included in a comparison (with results from the original code).

attribute.name: compare-flags
attribute.para: Specific settings for comparing this directory with the results of the original code. See below for details.

attribute.name: clear-target
attribute.para: Whether to clear the target directory before copying.

element.name: include
element.para: Definition of any files to include. See include/exclude elements

element.name: exclude
element.para: Definition of any files to exclude. See include/exclude elements

section.title: The empty-directory element
section.para: The empty-directory element creates an empty directory (underneath the setup's main target directory). If such a directory already exists it will be emptied (unless you set @clear-target="false", which will only be necessary in very rare circumstances).

attribute.name: target-subdir
attribute.para: The name of the sub-directory to create.

attribute.name: directory-id
attribute.para: Defines the identifier for the empty sub-directory. See common attributes for a usage example.

attribute.name: compare
attribute.para: Whether this directory should be included in a comparison (with results from the original code).

attribute.name: compare-flags
attribute.para: Specific settings for comparing this directory with the results of the original code. See below for details.

attribute.name: clear-target
attribute.para: Whether to clear the target directory.

section.title: The copy-directory element
section.para: The copy-directory element performs a straight copy from one directory to the other, including (optionally) subdirectories.

It was created for copying HTML assets to the result (but can of course also be used for other purposes). When you're copying from a directory in the code repository (which makes sense if it's a set of fixed asset files), use the #… notation for the @directory attribute. For instance directory="#mp/9.0.7/beschikbaarstellen_medicatiegegevens/html_instance_kwal/assets": the directory name after the # is relative to the data file it is used in.

attribute.name: target-subdir
attribute.para: The name of the sub-directory to copy the data to.

attribute.name: directory
attribute.para: The name of the source directory. See common attributes for special handling.

attribute.name: recurse
attribute.para: Whether to recurse into subdirectories and copy these as well.

attribute.name: directory-id
attribute.para: Defines the identifier for the target sub-directory. See common attributes for a usage example.

attribute.name: clear-target
attribute.para: Whether to clear the target directory before copying.

element.name: include
element.para: Definition of any files to include. See include/exclude elements

element.name: exclude
element.para: Definition of any files to exclude. See include/exclude elements

section.title: The retrieve element
section.para: The retrieve element specifies a single XML document for download from a REST URL.

attribute.name: target-subdir
attribute.para: The name of the sub-directory to copy the data to.

attribute.name: url
attribute.para: The REST URL to use for retrieving the XML document

attribute.name: name
attribute.para: The filename for the retrieved XML document.

attribute.name: directory-id
attribute.para: Defines the identifier for the target sub-directory. See common attributes for a usage example.

section.title: The compare-flags attribute
section.para: The compare-flags attribute sets some specific flags for comparing the results of the new with those of the original code. It was introduced because sometimes the code produces documents with generated filenames. These generated names differ between the new and the old code and therefore comparison is not possible. Its contents is a whitespace separated list of zero or more of the following strings:

entry.para: Do not compare files with names that are hexadecimal strings. For instance: d46e243.xml
Do not compare files with names that are UUIDs. For instance: 4b248570-6aa9-11ec-0000-020000000000.xml
Do not compare files with names that contain UUIDs. For instance: nl-core-organization-mp9-4b248570-6aa9-11ec-0000-020000000000.xml
